Do you have any source containers added to the default one?
And what is happening when you try to launch it again?
(In reply to comment #1)
> Do you have any source containers added to the default one?

No, just the default one for the app.  The workspace also includes projects that
build DLLs (and the app depends on those DLLs), but they are not listed in the
Debug As -> C++ Local Application -> Source Tab window.

> And what is happening when you try to launch it again?

Actually, now it won't debug at all (by 'debug' I mean 'have full debugging
capabilities integrated into the Eclipse/CDT IDE').  On eclipse startup, I
rebuild the project(s), then choose Debug As -> C++ Local Application for the
app.  At that point, *gdb is successfully started*, and I get a popup window saying
  'An internal error occurred during: "Launching"'

That's when the stackdump I posted appears in the log.

When I click OK to dismiss the popup, the gdb remains resident.  If I (manually)
switch to the Debug perspective, I can use the gdb process console to manually
run, debug, set breakpoints, etc -- but none of my actions are reflected in the
gui.  That is, if I set a breakpoint ('break app.cc:20' , 'continue') it works
-- execution will stop on line 20 -- but the breakpoint doesn't show up in the
Breakpoint view, nor does the little blue dot symbol show up in the Editor view.
I also can't double-click in the vertical ruler in the Editor View to set a
breakpoint.  Basically, the only working communication between Eclipse IDE and
gdb is the console.

FWIW, I'm using Eclipse 3.1.1 and CDT 3.0.1.
(In reply to comment #1)
> Do you have any source containers added to the default one?

Oh, another thing: I can't add sources to the Debug using the Project selection:
 In the Source Panel of the Debug... dialog, I click on Add... and get the 'Add
Source' dialog.  Then I select 'Project' and click OK, which gives me a
'Selection Needed' dialog containing a list of the projects in my workspace.  I
click 'select all' then 'OK' -- but that doesn't work.  It simply returns me to
the 'Add Source' dialog and does NOT add anything to the underlying Source Panel
of the Debug... dialog.

So, I tried selecting 'File System Directory with Subfolders' in the 'Add
Source' dialog.  This actually works, in that I can successfully add something
to the Source Panel.

But debugging still fails as described above: 'An internal error occurred
during: "Launching"'

All of the projects use linked resources to an 'outside' directory specified
with a path variable (Window->Preferences->General:Workspace:LinkedResources).

I noticed that when it was "working", Debug view looked something like this:

app.exe [C/C++ Local Application]
 +-- GDB Debugger (timestamp) (Suspended)
      +-- Thread[1] (Suspended)
          +-- 1 main() at C:\full\path\to\app.c 
 +-- Debugger Process (timestamp)
 +-- C:\full\path\to\app.exe

but when it was "broken" (e.g. could still debug "manually" using the gdb
console) it looked like

app.exe [C/C++ Local Application]
 +-- Debugger Process (timestamp)
 +-- C:\full\path\to\app.exe
It seems that your source lookup path contains a corruprt source container. If 
your project references some other projects (you mentioned DLL projects), check 
the referenced projects.
(In reply to comment #4)
> It seems that your source lookup path contains a corruprt source container. If 
> your project references some other projects (you mentioned DLL projects), check 
> the referenced projects.
> 

Well, *none* of the projects actually had explicit "Source Folders"; they simply
had linked resources that contained the source.  (e.g. .cdtproject had an entry
that looked like:

<item id="org.eclipse.cdt.core.pathentry">
<pathentry kind="src" path=""/>
<pathentry kind="out" path=""/>
<pathentry kind="con" path="org.eclipse.cdt.managedbuilder.MANAGED_CONTAINER"/>
</item>

BUT the project had a linked resource defined in the .project file like the
following (where VOBVIEWPATH is a Linked Resources Path Variable set via
Window->Preferences->General->Workspace->LinkedResources):

<linkedResources>
 <link>
  <name>sample</name>
  <type>2</type>
  <location>VOBVIEWPATH/src/igs/sample</location>
 </link>
</linkedResources>

I tried creating a "File->New->Source Folder" in the project with the same name
as the existing linked resource such that <pathentry kind="src" path="sample"/>
appeared in the project.  I ignored the warning about "To avoid overlapping, the
existing project source folder entry will be replaced.".

After repeating the procedure in all affected projects, things now SEEM to be
working properly[*] -- I can use the GUI to single-step, the Editor View PC
marker in ruler area advances to each line as I single-step, the Variable View
is updated, etc.

I'll keep my fingers crossed.

[*] still can't double-click in the Editor View's ruler area to set breakpoints.
 Should I open a new bug report?  Supposedly this was fixed in #49587 in Jan04
but...
(In reply to comment #5)
 
> After repeating the procedure in all affected projects, things now SEEM to be
> working properly[*] -- I can use the GUI to single-step, the Editor View PC
> marker in ruler area advances to each line as I single-step, the Variable View
> is updated, etc.

I spoke too soon.  It's broken again.  What the heck is going on?  IMO "Internal
Error" is a BUG, not a "you didn't set up the project correctly".  I don't
understand why the project settings are 'good enough' for the builder to produce
an executable, but not good enough to prevent a NullPointerException when trying
to debug that same app.  That's just screwy.

Let's go back to the basics: you said "your source lookup path contains a
corrupt source container"  Ooookay, so how did it get 'corrupted', and how do I
fix it?

You said "If your project references some other projects ... check the
referenced projects."  'Check'?  Whaddaya mean 'Check' -- 'determine if the
referenced projects are somehow "good"', or 'put a check mark in the box next to
the required libs in app_project's Properties->ProjectReferences'?   If the
latter, then that has always been true.  If the former...how?

I'm getting a little frustrated in that I see no difference in the project
settings when "it works" and when "it's broken".  It seems random.  I'll make
some change -- like the 'Source Folder' thing described above -- and suddenly
it'll work.  A few debug sessions later, with no settings modifications by me,
and suddenly it'll stop working and I'm back to square one: random fiddling in a
desperate attempt to get it "working" again.

Would it help if I sent a zip file containing a demonstration of the issue (of
course, given the apparent semi-randomness of the behavior there's no guarantee
it wouldn't "just work" when you got it)? 

> [*] still can't double-click in the Editor View's ruler area to set breakpoints.

AND all the breakpoint-related selections from the Run pulldown menu were grayed
out (this is referring to when the Launch was still successful...)

(In reply to comment #6)
> (In reply to comment #5)
>    random fiddling in a

I switched to using the 1.4.2 jvm (previously was using 1.4.1) and it's working
again.  I tried this because one of the bugzilla entries (forgot which number)
seems to indicate that CDT requires 1.4.2.

I hope it keeps working and doesn't 'randomly' decide to break again...
 
> > [*] still can't double-click in the Editor View's ruler area to set breakpoints.
> 
> AND all the breakpoint-related selections from the Run pulldown menu were grayed
> out (this is referring to when the Launch was still successful...)

Interestingly, I can use the disassembly window to set breakboints, but not the
source code window.  'objdump -g' shows that absolute paths in 'C:/foo/bar.h'
format are encoded in the object files (at least, for MY source code.  Symbols
derived from mingw-runtime objects have some relative paths, but I don't care
about that; I'm not trying to debug mingw itself).
 
FYI, I need to uninstall all of [Msys/mingw/Eclipse/CDT/etc] and reinstall it so
I can develop 'Install Docs' for my team; my computer will be non-functional for
investigating this problem 'til Monday.
